Their disappearance initiated one of the biggest [[missing person]]s investigations in the history of Chicago.{{cite news|title=Sixty Years Later, the Case of the Elvis Presley-loving Grimes Sisters' Murders Remains Cold |date=December 24, 2016 |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/crime/elvis-presley-loving-grimes-sisters-found-dead-60-years-article-1.2922567 |publisher=New York Daily News |accessdate=February 22, 2018}} The girls' nude bodies were discovered alongside a deserted road in [[Willow Springs, Illinois|Willow Springs]] on January 22, 1957. Although the sisters' [[autopsy|autopsy reports]] concluded the two girls had been murdered within five hours of their last confirmed sighting, and that both girls had died of [[Shock (circulatory)|secondary shock]], numerous individuals attested to having seen the girls alive in the weeks between the night of December 28 and the subsequent discovery of their bodies.{{cite web |title=3634 South Damen Avenue to 4223 South Archer Avenue, Chicago, Illinois |url=http://mapq.st/ZUjCCw |publisher=[[MapQuest]]}} The murder of the Grimes sisters has been described by authors as a crime which "shattered the innocence" of Chicago.''The Two Lost Girls: The Mystery of the Grimes Sisters'' {{ISBN|978-1-892-52398-3}} p. 7 This case is also acknowledged as one of the most labor-intensive missing person and murder investigations in [[Cook County, Illinois|Cook County]],{{cite news|title=Chicago Grimes Sisters' Murders Hit 59 Years Without Answers |date=January 7, 2016 |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/feature/cold-case-spotlight/chicago-grimes-sisters-murders-hit-59-years-without-answers-n486401 |publisher=NBC News |accessdate=February 27, 2018}} and remains one of Chicago's most infamous [[cold case]]s.{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagonow.com/chicago-history-cop/2012/12/new-information-on-disappearance-of-grimes-sisters-chicagos-most-infamous-cold-case/|title=New Information on Disappearance of Grimes Sisters: Chicago's Most Infamous Cold Case|first=Ray|last=Johnson|date=December 27, 2012|publisher=|via=chicagonow.com}} ==Disappearance== On December 28, 1956, two of the seven''The Two Lost Girls: The Mystery of the Grimes Sisters'' {{ISBN|978-1-892-52398-3}} p. 10 children born to Joseph and Lorretta Grimes—sisters Barbara, 15, and Patricia, 12—opted to view a screening of the [[Elvis Presley]] film ''[[Love Me Tender (1956 film)|Love Me Tender]]'' at a [[Brighton Park, Chicago|Brighton]] theater.''Crimes of the Centuries: Notorious Crimes, Criminals, and Criminal Trials in American History'' {{ISBN|978-1-610-69594-7}} p. 325 Both girls have been described as being inseparable sisters,''The Two Lost Girls: The Mystery of the Grimes Sisters'' {{ISBN|978-1-892-52398-3}} p. 11 and attentive students at the [[Thomas Kelly High School]] and [[List of schools of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Chicago#Former K-8 schools in Chicago|St. Maurice]] high schools they respectively attended. They are also known to have been devoted fans of Elvis Presley. This particular occasion was the eleventh time the girls had viewed this particular film of Presley's,{{cite news|title=Death and the Maidens |date=March 20, 1997 |url=https://www.chicagoreader.com/chicago/death-and-the-maidens/Content?oid=892961 |publisher=Chicago Reader |accessdate=February 27, 2018}} and the sisters are known to have left their residence at approximately 7:30 p.m.,{{cite web|url=https://www.chicagoreader.com/chicago/death-and-the-maidens/Content?oid=892961|title=Death and the Maidens |first=Tamara|last=Shaffer|date=March 20, 1997|publisher=|via=chicagoreader.com}} having promised their mother they would be home before midnight.{{cite news|title=Sixty Years Later, the Case of the Elvis Presley-loving Grimes Sisters' Murders Remains Cold |date=December 24, 2016 |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/crime/elvis-presley-loving-grimes-sisters-found-dead-60-years-article-1.2922567 |publisher=New York Daily News |accessdate=March 22, 2018}}{{refn|group=n|Joseph and Lorretta Grimes had divorced in December 1951. The divorce had been on amicable terms, with all the Grimes children maintaining regular contact with their father.''The Two Lost Girls: The Mystery of the Grimes Sisters'' {{ISBN|978-1-892-52398-3}} p. 10}} The Brighton Theater was located approximately one-and-a-half miles from the girls' [[McKinley Park, Chicago|McKinley Park]] home, and Barbara and Patricia are presumed to have had approximately $2.50 in their possession at the time they left their home, with Barbara having been instructed to keep 50 [[Penny (United States coin)|cents]] of this money in the zipper of her wallet should the two girls opt to view the second screening of this film scheduled to be broadcast at the theater that evening.''The Two Lost Girls: The Mystery of the Grimes Sisters'' {{ISBN|978-1-892-52398-3}} p. 12 It is unknown how the sisters actually traveled to the Brighton Theater on this particular date, although they had invariably either walked or traveled by bus to this destination on previous occasions. A school friend of Patricia Grimes named Dorothy Weinert would later inform investigators she had been seated behind the girls with her own younger sister during the film, although Weinert and her sister had left the theater at the intermission of the double feature screened at the Brighton Theater that night, at approximately 9:30 p.m. As they had done so, Dorothy saw the Grimes sisters queueing to purchase popcorn.{{refn|group=n|Of the $2.50 in the sisters' possession on the night of their disappearance, $1.50 had been intended for the admission fee to the Brighton Theater for both girls; 50 cents had been given for two boxes of popcorn, and the final 50 [[Penny (United States coin)|cents]] had been intended as the fare for the bus ride home for both girls.''The Two Lost Girls: The Mystery of the Grimes Sisters'' {{ISBN|978-1-892-52398-3}} p. 71}} The two had seemed in good spirits, and neither Weinert sister noticed anything untoward in their demeanor. Both sisters stayed to view the second screening of ''Love Me Tender'', thus meaning they would be expected to return home at approximately 11:45 p.m. When the girls had not arrived home by midnight, their mother, Lorretta, sent their older sister, Theresa (aged 17), and brother Joey (aged 14) to wait by the bus stop located closest to the family home for their arrival. After three successive buses had driven by without either girl alighting at the designated stop, both siblings returned home. Having by this stage already unsuccessfully contacted the girls' friends in the hope her daughters may be at one of these addresses,{{cite news|title=Unsolved Chicago Grimes Sisters' Murder is 59 Years Old |date=December 26, 2015 |url=http://www.chicagonow.com/chicago-history-cop/2015/12/unsolved-chicago-grimes-sisters-murder-is-59-years-old/ |publisher=Chicago Now |accessdate=March 1, 2018}} and upon seeing the return of Theresa and Joey to the family home without their sisters, Lorretta Grimes filed missing person reports on her daughters with the [[Chicago Police Department]] at 2:15 a.m. on December 29. ===Investigation=== The disappearance of Barbara and Patricia Grimes sparked one of the biggest missing person cases in the history of [[Cook County, Illinois|Cook County]].''Chicago Haunts: Ghostlore of the Windy City'' {{ISBN|0-964-24269-9}} p. 141 A citywide search for the sisters was immediately initiated,''Open Files: A Narrative Encyclopedia of the World's Greatest Unsolved Crimes'' {{ISBN|978-0-07045-907-6}} p. 100 and hundreds of police officers were subsequently assigned full-time to the search for the missing sisters. The officers from Cook County were assisted by colleagues from surrounding suburbs, and a [[task force]] devoted solely to locating the sisters was formed,{{cite news|title=Unsolved Chicago Grimes Sisters' Murder is 59 Years Old |date=December 26, 2015 |url=http://www.chicagonow.com/chicago-history-cop/2015/12/unsolved-chicago-grimes-sisters-murder-is-59-years-old/ |publisher=Chicago Now |accessdate=March 1, 2018}} with the ground search for the sisters initiated on December 29 being bolstered by hundreds of local volunteers. Police conducted door-to-door canvassing throughout the neighborhood where Barbara and Patricia were last seen, and numerous canals and rivers were [[Dredging|dragged]]. In addition, more than 15,000 flyers were distributed to local homes, and parishioners of the church the sisters attended offered a $1,000 reward for information leading to their whereabouts.''The Two Lost Girls: The Mystery of the Grimes Sisters'' {{ISBN|978-1-892-52398-3}} p. 13 As a result of this co-ordinated investigation into the sisters' disappearance, 300,000 people would be [[Interrogation|interrogated]],''Chicago Haunts: Ghostlore of the Windy City'' {{ISBN|978-0-964-24267-8}} p. 141 with some 2,000 individuals subjected to serious interrogation pertaining to their potential culpability, although the two arrests and charges brought against individuals who [[confession|confessed]] to the crime subsequently collapsed, with one individual, Edward Benwell, asserting he had been [[coercion|coerced]] into providing a confession due to his being subjected to a prolonged interrogation.{{cite news|title=Chicago Grimes Sisters' Murders Hit 59 Years Without Answers |date=January 7, 2016 |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/feature/cold-case-spotlight/chicago-grimes-sisters-murders-hit-59-years-without-answers-n486401 |publisher=NBC News |accessdate=March 10, 2018}} Despite these interrogations, confessions, and extensive media appeals producing many reported sightings of the girls, little in the way of hard evidence was yielded, although several teenagers who had been at the Brighton Theater on December 28 did inform investigators they had seen the two girls conversing with, then entering a car driven by a young man whose physical appearance had been similar to that of Elvis Presley. The vehicle described by these eyewitnesses was consistently described as being a [[Mercury (automobile)|Mercury]] model. Prior to the implementation of this task force, and against vehement protestations to the contrary from the girls' parents, several investigators initially assigned to the case theorized the sisters may either have run away from home{{cite news|title=Two Chicago Girls Found Cruelly Slain. Boys' Murders Similarly Cited |date=January 23, 1957 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=861&dat=19570123&id=rjVQAAAAIBAJ&pg=6556,2060691 |publisher=The Victoria Advocate |accessdate=March 7, 2018}} or be voluntarily staying with boyfriends, and although the sisters' disappearance was front-page news by December 31, their disappearances would only be seriously considered as missing persons cases—and thus appropriately treated as such—by investigators after approximately one week had passed without family and friends receiving any form of contact from either girl.{{cite news|title=Unsolved Chicago Grimes Sisters' Murder is 59 Years Old |date=December 26, 2015 |url=http://www.chicagonow.com/chicago-history-cop/2015/12/unsolved-chicago-grimes-sisters-murder-is-59-years-old/ |publisher=Chicago Now |accessdate=March 1, 2018}} Nonetheless, extensive media appeals were conducted, imploring both sisters to return home, and for any [[eyewitness memory|eyewitnesses]] to contact police. Resultingly, numerous [[allegation|alleged]] sightings of the sisters would be reported to police as late as January 9, and these reports often described either or both of the girls as having been seen in various business establishments. These sightings supported several investigators' initial theories the girls had opted to leave home of their own accord. Theories also abounded that the sisters may possibly have traveled to [[Nashville]], [[Tennessee]], to see Elvis Presley in concert,{{refn|group=n|One of many eyewitness reports received by the Chicago Police Department in January 1957 came from an individual who claimed to have seen the girls at a bus station in Elvis Presley's home town; thus leading to the possibility the girls had traveled to [[Tennessee]] to visit their idol.{{cite news|title=Unsolved Chicago Grimes Sisters' Murder is 59 Years Old |date=December 26, 2015 |url=http://www.chicagonow.com/chicago-history-cop/2015/12/unsolved-chicago-grimes-sisters-murder-is-59-years-old/ |publisher=Chicago Now |accessdate=March 1, 2018}}}} or that the sisters had simply left their home of their own volition as a means of emulating Presley's lifestyle. In the event her daughters had actually been [[kidnapping|kidnapped]], Lorretta Grimes publicly pleaded: "If someone is holding them, please let the girls call me",{{cite news|title=Grimes Sisters' Deaths, Still Snsolved, Part of Series that Shook City in 1950s |date=January 22, 2012 |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/ct-per-flash-grimes-0122-20120123-story.html |publisher=Chicago Tribune |accessdate=March 17, 2018}} adding: "I'll forgive them from the bottom of my heart."{{cite news|title=Death and the Maidens |date=March 20, 1997 |url=https://www.chicagoreader.com/chicago/death-and-the-maidens/Content?oid=892961 |publisher=Chicago Reader |accessdate=March 22, 2018}} On January 19, 1957, an official statement was issued from Presley's [[Graceland|Graceland estate]]. This televised{{cite web|url=https://www.thetalko.com/15-things-we-know-about-the-unsolved-murders-of-the-grimes-sisters/|title=15 Things to Know About the Unsolved Murders of the Grimes Sisters|date=May 7, 2017|publisher=thetalkto.com}} statement read: "If you are good Presley fans, you'll go home and ease your mother's worries." Presley is also known to have made a direct radio plea to the Grimes sisters, imploring the girls to return home to their mother.Nash, Jay Robert. ''Open Files: A Narrative Encyclopedia of the World's Greatest Unsolved Crimes''; Mcgraw-Hill; April 1983; {{ISBN|978-0-070-45907-6}} [[File:Grimes Crime Scene.jpg|thumb|200px|Investigators converge alongside German Church Road, January 22, 1957, following the discovery of the bodies of Barbara and Patricia Grimes.]] ==Discovery== On January 22, 1957, following a rapid thaw of recent snowfall,{{cite news|title=Skid Row Drifter Says He and Crony Tossed 2 Sisters Out of Car (page 2)|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=FRxSAAAAIBAJ&pg=5441,5967451|accessdate=April 2, 2013|newspaper=St. Petersburg Times|date=January 28, 1957|author=AP}} a construction worker named Leonard Prescott spotted what he later described as being "these flesh-colored things"{{cite news|title=Sixty Years Later, the Case of the Elvis Presley-loving Grimes Sisters' Murders Remains Cold |date=December 24, 2016 |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/crime/elvis-presley-loving-grimes-sisters-found-dead-60-years-article-1.2922567 |publisher=New York Daily News |accessdate=March 6, 2018}} behind a guard rail as he drove along a rural country road named German Church Road, approximately 200 feet east of County Line Road in [[unincorporated area|unincorporated]] [[Willow Springs, Illinois|Willow Springs]]. Initially unsure of the origin of what he had seen, and believing the forms may be [[mannequin]]s, Prescott later returned to the site with his wife, Marie, who herself fainted upon taking a closer look at what her husband had earlier seen. The mannequins were actually the nude, frozen bodies of the Grimes girls, and the Prescotts immediately reported their findings to the Willow Springs Police Department.{{refn|group=n|Upon hearing of the discovery of her daughters' bodies, Lorretta Grimes would lament: "My poor babies. If the police had listened to me they would have had the true story half an hour after [the girls] were missing."{{cite news|title=Sixty Years Later, the Case of the Elvis Presley-loving Grimes Sisters' Murders Remains Cold |date=December 24, 2016 |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/crime/elvis-presley-loving-grimes-sisters-found-dead-60-years-article-1.2922567 |accessdate=February 27, 2018}}}}{{refn|group=n|Initially, both investigators and the media speculated the Grimes sisters' murders may be linked to the [[Silas Jayne#Peterson-Schuessler murders|murders of three Chicago schoolboys]] whose nude bodies had been found in a [[nature reserve|forest preserve]] in October 1955, with Cook County Sheriff [[Joseph D. Lohman|Joseph Lohman]] stating there had been "remarkable similarities" in both cases of multiple murder.{{cite news|title=Two Chicago Girls Found Cruelly Slain. Boys' Murders Similarly Cited |date=January 23, 1957 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=861&dat=19570123&id=rjVQAAAAIBAJ&pg=6556,2060691 |publisher=The Victoria Advocate (p. 12) |accessdate=March 7, 2018}} Another individual would be convicted of the 1955 triple homicide in 2002.{{cite news|title=Death Closes the Case of Boys’ Murders |date=September 16, 2007 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/09/16/us/16illinois.html |publisher=The New York Times |accessdate=March 7, 2018}}}} The girls' bodies lay upon a flat, horizontal section of snow-covered ground directly behind the guard rail which extended for just {{convert|10|ft}} before the incline of the embankment of a creek known simply as Devil's Creek.''The Two Lost Girls: The Mystery of the Grimes Sisters'' {{ISBN|978-1-892-52398-3}} p. 34 Barbara Grimes lay on her left side, with her legs drawn slightly up toward her torso. Patricia Grimes lay on her back, with her body covering her sister's head, and her own head turned sharply to the right. It is believed the sisters had most likely been driven to this location in a car, with their bodies then being dragged or lifted out of the vehicle, then placed or thrown behind the guard rail.{{cite news|last=Shaffer|first=Tamara|title=Death and the Maidens|url=http://www.chicagoreader.com/chicago/death-and-the-maidens/Content?oid=892961|accessdate=March 26, 2013|newspaper=Chicago Reader|date=March 20, 1997}} Three wounds resembling those typically inflicted by ice-picks were discovered upon Barbara's chest and injuries resembling [[blunt force trauma]] were visible upon her face and head,''The Two Lost Girls: The Mystery of the Grimes Sisters'' {{ISBN|978-1-892-52398-3}} p. 39 whereas numerous injuries resembling bruises were also discovered upon Patricia's face and body.''Crimes of the Centuries: Notorious Crimes, Criminals, and Criminal Trials in American History'' {{ISBN|978-1-610-69594-7}} p. 326 The girls' father, Joseph Grimes, was driven to the [[crime scene]] to formally identify both his daughters' bodies.{{cite news|title=Unsolved Chicago Grimes Sisters' Murder is 59 Years Old |date=December 26, 2015 |url=http://www.chicagonow.com/chicago-history-cop/2015/12/unsolved-chicago-grimes-sisters-murder-is-59-years-old/ |publisher=Chicago Now |accessdate=March 1, 2018}}{{refn|group=n|Upon his arrival at the [[crime scene]], Joseph Grimes simply glanced at the bodies before stating, "Yes, they are my daughters" before slumping forward in bouts of tears. He had to be supported from the scene by police officers. Given Joseph Grimes' evident distress, another family relative later made a formal identification of the girls in a Cook County morgue.''The Two Lost Girls: The Mystery of the Grimes Sisters'' {{ISBN|978-1-892-52398-3}} p. 35}} Following Joseph Grimes' initial positive identification of the bodies, over 160 police officers from several [[Chicago metropolitan area|suburban Chicago]] police departments—assisted by numerous local volunteers—''The Two Lost Girls: The Mystery of the Grimes Sisters'' {{ISBN|978-1-892-52398-3}} p. 37 conducted a search of the crime scene with the additional assistance of the [[Nature reserve|Forest Preserves]]. This search uncovered little or no [[real evidence]] linked to the crime (any potential link any item discovered at the crime scene had to the murders has never been determined),{{cite news|title= Sisters' Bodies Found: Nude, Pierced By Killer |date=January 23, 1957 |url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/100944620/ |publisher=The Cincinnati Enquirer |accessdate=March 30, 2018}} and the search itself would later be severely criticized due to those organizing the search allowing untrained individuals to trample over any evidence which may have been at the location.''The Two Lost Girls: The Mystery of the Grimes Sisters'' {{ISBN|978-1-892-52398-3}} pp. 37-38{{refn|group=n|Several hours after the discovery of the girls' bodies, the area surrounding the discovery would be appropriately cordoned until the scene could be appropriately examined by crime scene experts.''The Two Lost Girls: The Mystery of the Grimes Sisters'' {{ISBN|978-1-892-52398-3}} p. 38}} ===Autopsies=== The decedents' autopsies were performed the day following their discovery. These autopsies would be performed by three experienced [[forensic pathology|forensic pathologist]]s who, following a five-hour examination of each body,''Unsolved Child Murders: Eighteen American Cases, 1956–1998'' {{ISBN|978-1-476-67000-3}} p. 7 were unable to reach agreement on either a date or a cause of death. These experts did determine via an examination of the sisters' stomach contents (which contained the approximate proportions of the last known meal and subsequent snack the sisters had eaten on the evening of December 28''The Two Lost Girls: The Mystery of the Grimes Sisters'' {{ISBN|978-1-892-52398-3}} pp. 11-12) that both sisters had most likely died within approximately five hours of the time they had last been seen alive at the Brighton Theater, thus affixing the most likely time of death in each instance to have been either the late evening of December 28 or the early morning of December 29. The cause of death in each case was ruled as being a combination of [[Shock (circulatory)|shock]] and [[Hypothermia|exposure]], although each pathologist reached this conclusion via a process of eliminating other causes. In addition, these experts concluded that many of the wounds discovered upon the girls' bodies had most likely been inflicted by rodents, with the actual puncture wounds having most likely been inflicted after death.''The Two Lost Girls: The Mystery of the Grimes Sisters'' {{ISBN|978-1-892-52398-3}} p. 48 [[File:Barbara Grimes autopsy report.jpg|thumb|right|180px|[[Death certificate]] of Barbara Grimes.]] No obviously fatal wounds were discovered upon either girl's body, and [[toxicology]] reports revealed that neither girl had been drunk, drugged, or poisoned prior to her death. No items of the sisters' clothing were ever found, although their bodies were described by the pathologists as being markedly clean.''The Two Lost Girls: The Mystery of the Grimes Sisters'' {{ISBN|978-1-892-52398-3}} p. 14 The autopsies would also discover that Barbara Grimes had likely engaged in sexual intercourse—either [[Consent|consensually]] or [[rape|unconsensually]]—around the time of her death, although no evidence of forcible molestation was found. The official [[death certificate]]s of both Barbara and Patricia would list their [[cause of death]] as being [[murder]];{{cite news|title=Grimes Sisters Murders - 60 Years Ago |date=December 27, 2016 |url=http://viplocal.com.au/2016/09/20/grimes-sisters-murder/ |publisher=The Local |accessdate=March 11, 2018}} the specific means of which, in both cases, was listed as being "secondary shock" resulting from exposure to low temperatures, which had reduced each girl's [[Thermoregulation|body temperature]] "below the critical level compatible with life."{{cite news|title=Doctors Say Exposure Killed Grimes Sisters|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ISVSAAAAIBAJ&pg=1751,3632936|accessdate= March 21, 2013|newspaper=St. Petersburg Times|date=February 9, 1957|author=UP}}{{refn|group=n|Although the official [[forensic pathology|pathological]] report attributed the girls' deaths to exposure, in an interview given to the ''News and Courier,'' one of the doctors referred to the deaths as "brutal homicides", adding: "Those girls could not have died [[Death by natural causes|naturally]]."{{cite news|title=Grimes Sisters' Murder: Ray Johnson Wants to Solve Unsolved Deaths of Barbara and Patricia Grimes |date=May 31, 2013 |url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/05/31/grimes-sisters-murder-ray-johnson-solve_n_3366069.html |accessdate=March 3, 2018}}}} One of the coroners to perform the autopsies, Walter McCarron, surmised the sisters' bodies had lain undiscovered behind the guard rail on German Church Road for many days before their eventual discovery, stating that the bodies' markedly preserved condition given the time interval between their disappearance and discovery had been due the frigid temperatures in the weeks prior to January 22, adding that this had been due to recent snowfalls and the frigid climate. McCarron also concluded the girls' bodies had lain undiscovered for more than three weeks because a layer of snow had blanketed the area on January 9, and that this snowfall had rapidly melted in the days immediately prior to their discovery.{{cite news|title=Two Chicago Girls Found Cruelly Slain: Boys' Murders Similarly Cited |date=January 23, 1957 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=861&dat=19570123&id=rjVQAAAAIBAJ&pg=6556,2060691 |accessdate=March 1, 2018}} Despite these official conclusions, the Chief Investigator for the Cook County Coroner's Office, Harry Glos,{{cite news|last=O'Brien|first=John|title=Window To Past Crimes - Files Of Ex-coroner Aide May Help Solve Murders|page=1|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1994-09-25/news/9409250312_1_murder-case-peterson-case-kenneth-hansen|accessdate=March 20, 2013|newspaper=Chicago Tribune|date=September 25, 1994}} disagreed with the official time of death, later stating to the media there had been numerous "marks of violence on those girls' faces" strongly indicative of their being the recipients of violence as opposed to [[postmortem]] rodent infestation.''The Two Lost Girls: The Mystery of the Grimes Sisters'' {{ISBN|978-1-892-52398-3}} p. 87 Glos also contended that a thin layer of ice found encrusted upon the sisters' bodies indicated they had most likely been alive until at least January 7, since only after that date would there have been sufficient snowfall to react with the girls' natural body heat in such a climate and thus create the layer of ice discovered upon their nude bodies in this location. Glos contended this fact proved their bodies had been warm when their bodies had been deposited beside German Church Road, since only after January 7 had there been sufficient snow to create such an ice layer upon and around their bodies. In addition to these facts, Glos also stated that both girls had been subjected to sexual assaults throughout their period of captivity, adding that the autopsy conducted upon Patricia Grimes had discovered [[semen]] within the [[Vaginal discharge|vaginal fluid]] swathed from her body, and that curdled milk had also been found in Barbara Grimes' stomach, when she is not known to have drunk milk either at her home or at the cinema on the evening of December 28.''The Two Lost Girls: The Mystery of the Grimes Sisters'' {{ISBN|978-1-892-52398-3}} p. 88 ==Official controversies== The chief investigator of the Cook County coroner's office, Harry Glos, strongly believed an official suspect in the case named Edward Bedwell had been the individual who had committed the sisters' murder. Glos asserted the wound marks noted upon the girls' bodies in their autopsies had neither been adequately investigated or considered. Glos would also further assert his opinion the wounding and assault marks had been evidence that the sisters had been beaten prior to their murder and, in tandem with the evidence of sexual activity, were thus in line with the claims Edward Bedwell provided to investigators in his January 1957 interrogations.{{refn|group=n|Glos would also assert the autopsy reports, in conjunction with circumstantial evidence, unequivocally revealed that both sisters had been held captive for a minimum of 10 days prior to their murder, adding that throughout the period of their captivity, both girls had been subjected to repeated beatings, torture, and sexual assaults.''The Two Lost Girls: The Mystery of the Grimes Sisters'' {{ISBN|978-1-892-52398-3}} p. 131}} Harry Glos would also claim that official investigators had been refusing to disclose these and potentially other lurid details of the case''The Two Lost Girls: The Mystery of the Grimes Sisters'' {{ISBN|978-1-892-52398-3}} p. 89 due to a possible desire to protect the girls' reputations and/or spare their mother's feelings.{{cite news|title=Grimes Sisters' Deaths, Still Unsolved, Part of Series that Shook City in 1950s |date=January 22, 2012 |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2012-01-22/site/ct-per-flash-grimes-0122-20120123_1_cold-cases-bodies-grimes-sisters |publisher=Chicago Tribune |accessdate=September 6, 2018}} Similar allegations would be repeated in later years by others, some of whom claimed to have both seen the original case files, and to have interviewed numerous McKinley Park residents who alleged both girls had been in the habit of spending free time outside bars on 36th Street and Archer Avenue, where they regularly persuaded older men to purchase alcoholic drinks inside these premises and deliver the beverages to them outside the premises.{{cite news|title=Grimes Sisters' Deaths, Still Unsolved, Part of Series that Shook City in 1950s |date=January 22, 2012 |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/ct-per-flash-grimes-0122-20120123-story.html |publisher=Chicago Tribune |accessdate=March 17, 2018}}''The Two Lost Girls: The Mystery of the Grimes Sisters'' {{ISBN|978-1-892-52398-3}} p. 130 Despite Glos's insistence that the pathologists had "[taken] the girls off Madison Street and put them into respectability", investigators connected to the case continued to insist that there had been no evidence of either girl being disreputable, or the recipient of extreme violence or sexual molestation prior to her death.{{cite news|author=UP|title=Grimes Case Tiff Costs Job - Coroner's Aide Backed by Detective Chief, but Is Fired|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1499&dat=19570216&id=IDEaAAAAIBAJ&pg=7201,15952|accessdate=March 20, 2013|newspaper=The Milwaukee Journal|date=February 16, 1957}} After refusing to retract his statements, Glos was fired by Coroner Walter E. McCarron on February 15,{{cite news|title=Prober Is Fired After Charging Grimes Cover Up |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1964&dat=19570216&id=x-EiAAAAIBAJ&pg=2427,3055026 |accessdate=April 2, 2013 |newspaper=The Palm Beach Post |date=February 16, 1957 |author=UP}}{{Dead link|date=July 2018}} although he (Glos) would insist his firing had been politically motivated. Nonetheless, Glos would later be deputized by Sheriff [[Joseph D. Lohman|Joseph Lohman]]—who concurred with Glos's conviction the girls had likely been beaten and tortured by a sexual predator who had lured them into his vehicle upon an innocent pretense—to continue to work on the case without pay. ==Sightings== Between the last confirmed sighting of the sisters at the Brighton Theater on December 28, 1956, and the subsequent discovery of their bodies 25 days later, several unconfirmed sightings of the girls both in and outside the City of Chicago were reported to the Chicago Police Department. The most widely reported sightings include the following: * Numerous people stated to investigators they had seen the girls boarding a [[Chicago Transit Authority]] bus on Archer Avenue heading east into the city after the screening. Those to report this sighting to police included the bus driver. The sisters [[allegation|allegedly]] alighted this bus at Western Avenue, approximately halfway between the theater and their home, at approximately 11:05 p.m. Why the sisters would alight the bus at Western Avenue is unknown.{{cite news|title=Death and the Maidens |date=February 20, 1997 |url=https://www.chicagoreader.com/chicago/death-and-the-maidens/Content?oid=892961 |publisher=Chicago Reader |accessdate=March 2, 2018}}{{refn|group=n|Investigators would question the accuracy of at least part of this sighting due to the fact the bus driver would state he believed he had heard the sisters mentioning their intention to board an oncoming northbound Western Avenue trolley, which traveled in the direction opposite their home.''The Two Lost Girls: The Mystery of the Grimes Sisters'' {{ISBN|978-1-892-52398-3}} p. 27}} * A young man named Roger Menard informed investigators he had also attended the screening of ''Love me Tender'' on the evening of December 28, having sat behind Barbara and Patricia Grimes and close to Dorothy Weinert. According to Menard, he had left the theater approximately one minute before the Grimes sisters, and the two girls had walked down Archer Avenue a short distance behind him before a "late model, green [[Buick]]" had stopped alongside them. The two girls hesitated, before continuing walking. Just past 42nd Street, with the sisters by this stage walking ahead of him, a black [[Mercury Eight#1949–1951|1949 Mercury]] occupied by two teenage boys pulled alongside the girls, although the sisters simply giggled before continuing walking in the direction of their home.''The Two Lost Girls: The Mystery of the Grimes Sisters'' {{ISBN|978-1-892-52398-3}} pp. 77-79 * Two teenage boys named Ed Lorden and Earl Zastro informed investigators that while they had been driving through McKinley Park at approximately 11:30 p.m. on December 28, they had seen the sisters on 35th Street. Reportedly, the two had been "giggling and jumping out of doorways at each other" near Seely and Damen Avenues, with one youth exclaiming to the other the two were "those two Grimes sisters" as they passed them. At this point the girls would have been approximately two blocks from their home. * A security guard named Jack Franklin later informed investigators he had offered directions to two girls on the morning of December 29, approximately 12 hours after they had left the theater. This verbal exchange had allegedly occurred near Lawrence and Central Park Avenues, and Franklin later concluded the girls had been the Grimes sisters, adding the sole reason he had recalled this conversation was that both girls had been both rude and abrupt to him. * On the same date of Franklin's alleged sighting of Barbara and Patricia, a friend of Barbara's named Judy Burrow reported to investigators she had seen the sisters at approximately 2:30 p.m., walking westward on Archer Avenue (two blocks from Damen Avenue).''The Two Lost Girls: The Mystery of the Grimes Sisters'' {{ISBN|978-1-892-52398-3}} p. 27 [[File:Patricia_Grimes_Autopsy_report.jpg|thumb|right|180px|Death certificate of Patricia Grimes.]] * A classmate of Patricia Grimes named Catherine Borak was adamant she had seen Patricia walking past a restaurant she (Borak) had been inside in the early evening of December 29. According to Borak, Patricia had been in the company of two unidentified young girls. This sighting was followed by another, six hours later, by a cashier at the Clark Theater in downtown Chicago, who claimed she had seen both girls at 12:45 a.m. * A railroad conductor named Bernard Norton reported seeing the two girls aboard a train near the Great Lakes Naval Training Center in north suburban [[Glenview, Cook County, Illinois|Glenview]]. According to Norton, the two girls had been searching for two sailors named "Terry" and "Larry."''The Two Lost Girls: The Mystery of the Grimes Sisters'' {{ISBN|978-1-892-52398-3}} p. 27 * On December 30 at 5:40 am, the owner of the D&L Restaurant at 1340 West Madison said he had seen both girls, with Patricia apparently too drunk or sick to walk without staggering, accompanied by an official suspect named Edward Bedwell. This location was over five-and-a-half miles from the Brighton Theater.{{cite web|title=4223 South Archer Avenue to 1340 West Madison, Chicago, IL|url=http://mapq.st/ZLsagy|publisher=mapquest}} A clerk at the Claremont Hotel, after viewing the bodies at a mortuary, likewise identified the sisters as having checked into the hotel on this date.{{cite news|title=Suspect In Chicago Murders Admits, Then Denies Crime|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=gJpCAAAAIBAJ&pg=5268,1111939|accessdate=March 21, 2013|newspaper=Middlesboro Daily News|date=January 26, 1957|author=UP}} * On January 1, 1957, the girls were reported as having been seen aboard a Chicago Transit Authority bus on Damen Avenue.''True Crime: Illinois: The State's Most Notorious Criminal Cases'' {{ISBN|978-0-811-73562-9}} p. 102 * The following week, a night clerk at the Unity Hotel on West 61st street refused two girls a room because of their age. This clerk believed the girls in question had been the Grimes sisters. * On January 3, three employees at an [[Englewood, Chicago|Englewood]] Kresge department store claimed to have seen both girls listening to music at the store's record counter. Each employee stated the sisters had been listening to music by Elvis Presley. * Adding credence to the theory that both sisters had run away to Nashville, on January 17, a woman named Pearl Neville contacted investigators to state she had met both girls in a restroom in this location on January 9, and that she had accompanied them to a state employment agency to search for work. According to Neville, both girls had been in what she described as being a "tired, bedraggled" condition. A clerk at this agency would later identify the sisters from photographs, also recalling that both girls had used the surname "Grimes" in the application forms they had populated.''The Two Lost Girls: The Mystery of the Grimes Sisters'' {{ISBN|978-1-892-52398-3}} p. 30 * In the early hours of January 14, the parents of a classmate of Patricia Grimes named Sandra Tollstan received two separate, anonymous telephone calls. During the first call, nobody at the other end spoke. Picking up the second phone call approximately 15 minutes later, Sandra's mother, Ann, heard a "frightened and depressed" young female voice asking, "Is that you, Sandra? Is Sandra there?" Before Ann could bring her daughter to the phone, the call had been terminated. Mrs. Tollstan informed investigators of her conviction that the caller had been Patricia Grimes. {{quote box | quote = "Outside the show we all got to talking and we exchanged phone numbers. When we got to the street where we turned off, we said goodbye and we ran across the street. Then Betty forgot something she had to tell Barbara and we ran back to the corner ... A man about 22 or 25 was talking to them. He pushed Barbara in the back seat of the car and Pat in the front seat. We got part of the license number as the car drove by us. The first four numbers were 2184. Betty thinks there were three or four numbers after that ... When we heard that they were missing we didn't know what to do." | source = Section of an anonymous letter sent to ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'' [[columnist|advice columnist]] [[Ask Ann Landers|Ann Landers]], January 1957.''Open Files: A Narrative Encyclopedia of the World's Greatest Unsolved Crimes'' {{ISBN|978-0-07045-907-6}} p. 101 | width = 30em }} * Following the January 19 television and radio appeal by Elvis Presley imploring the sisters to return home, a ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'' [[columnist|advice columnist]] named [[Ask Ann Landers|Ann Landers]] received an anonymous letter, allegedly written by a girl who claimed to have witnessed the sisters being forced into a car by a young male on the night of their disappearance. Although a partial license number was provided with this letter, subsequent police endeavors to trace the vehicle proved fruitless. The author of this letter was never identified, and the actual contents were never authenticated.''The Encyclopedia of Unsolved Crimes'' {{ISBN|978-0-816-07818-9}} p. 76 ==Suspects== ===Edward Bedwell=== Edward Lee "Bennie" Bedwell{{cite news|title=Skid Row Dishwasher Admits Slugging 2 Sisters To Death|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=336&dat=19570128&id=pqkuAAAAIBAJ&pg=7049,4785677|accessdate=March 19, 2013|newspaper=The Deseret News|date=January 28, 1957|author=UP}} was a 21-year-old semi-[[Literacy|literate]] drifter, originally from Tennessee, who had been evicted from his family's [[East Garfield Park, Chicago|East Garfield Park]] home in November 1956''The Two Lost Girls: The Mystery of the Grimes Sisters'' {{ISBN|978-1-892-52398-3}} p. 57 and in the weeks preceding the Grimes sisters' murder had occasionally earned money by working as a part-time dishwasher in a Chicago [[Skid row#Chicago|skid row]] restaurant. Bedwell was a tall individual who allegedly bore a strong resemblance to Elvis Presley. According to John and Minnie Duros (the owners of the restaurant where Bedwell had been employed), he and another young male had been at her premises in the company of two girls who physically resembled{{cite news|title=Unsolved Chicago Grimes Sisters' Murder is 59 Years Old |date=December 26, 2015 |url=http://www.chicagonow.com/chicago-history-cop/2015/12/unsolved-chicago-grimes-sisters-murder-is-59-years-old/ |publisher=Chicago Now |accessdate=March 20, 2018}} the Grimes sisters in the early morning of December 30.''True Crime: Illinois: The State's Most Notorious Criminal Cases'' {{ISBN|978-0-811-73562-9}} p. 107 Duros conveyed this information to police on January 24. Bedwell was arrested thereafter and subjected to interrogation for three days.{{cite book|last=Shaffer|first=Tamara|title=Murder Gone Cold - The Mystery of the Grimes Sisters|year=2006|publisher=Ghost Research Society Press|isbn=9780976607274|page=55|url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Murder_Gone_Cold.html?id=lWX_PQAACAAJ}} Initially, Bedwell was insistent that John and Minnie Duros and a patron named Rene Echols (who had [[corroborating evidence|corroborated]] the Duros's eyewitness statements) were mistaken in their identification of the girls he had been in the company of on December 30, although he was formally charged with the sisters' murders on January 27, 1957, having signed a 14-page confession in which he claimed that he (Bedwell) and a 28-year-old acquaintance of his named William Cole Willingham''Crimes of the Centuries: Notorious Crimes, Criminals, and Criminal Trials in American History'' {{ISBN|978-1-610-69594-7}} p. 326 had indeed been in the company of the Grimes sisters on December 30, having also retained their company until January 7—typically drinking in various West Madison Street skid row saloons.{{cite news|title=Bedwell Charged in Sister Slayings|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=xyMoAAAAIBAJ&pg=6699,3570982|accessdate=March 21, 2013|newspaper=The Milwaukee Journal|date=January 28, 1957|author=Associated Press}} According to Bedwell, after several days in the girls' willing company, shortly after he and his companion had fed the sisters hot dogs,{{cite news|title=Skid Row Drifter Says He and Crony Tossed 2 Sisters Out of Car (page 1)|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=FRxSAAAAIBAJ&pg=3776,5896143|accessdate=April 28, 2013|newspaper=St. Petersburg Times|date=January 28, 1957|author=AP}} they had extensively beaten both girls, before throwing their nude bodies into a snow-filled ditch{{cite news|title=The Grimes Case: Another Chapter to Grim Story |date=January 28, 1957 |url=http://www.pantagraph.com/the-grimes-sisters-dec/article_6d693a7a-52bd-11e5-a1b3-3fd833c3ae00.html|publisher=pantagraph.com |accessdate=March 15, 2018}} when both sisters had refused their sexual advances.{{cite news|title=Chicago Grimes Sisters' Murders Hit 59 Years Without Answers |date=January 7, 2016 |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/feature/cold-case-spotlight/chicago-grimes-sisters-murders-hit-59-years-without-answers-n486401 |publisher=NBC News |accessdate=March 12, 2018}} Upon reading Bedwell's confession, Lorretta Grimes was quoted upon as stating: "It's a lie. My girls wouldn't be on West Madison Street. They didn't even know where it was." Willingham admitted he had been in the company of Bedwell and two girls in the early hours of December 30, but denied the girls had been the Grimes sisters.''True Crime: Illinois: The State's Most Notorious Criminal Cases'' {{ISBN|978-0-811-73562-9}} p. 108 He also emphatically denied any involvement in the murders; Bedwell himself would later [[recantation|recant]] the confession he had provided to investigators, stating that he had only provided a confession after being held in custody for four days in the mistaken belief the police would subsequently release him if he did so.{{refn|group=n|At the commencement of a three-day [[habeas corpus]] hearing beginning January 31, Edward Bedwell testified he had concocted his confession due to his being the recipient of threats, bribery, and occasional physical violence throughout his interrogations.{{cite news|title=Death and the Maidens |date=March 20, 1997 |url=https://www.chicagoreader.com/chicago/death-and-the-maidens/Content?oid=892961 |publisher=Chicago Reader |accessdate=March 23, 2018}}}}{{refn|group=n|Two teenage cousins named Irene Dean (age 19) and Carol King (age 18) would later inform investigators they had likely been the two girls who had accompanied Bedwell and Willingham to the restaurant in the early hours of either December 29 or 30. Dean would state her cousin had "paired off" with Willingham while she (Dean) had been Bedwell's date. Minnie Duros would recollect having seen Irene Dean in the restaurant on other dates, but never in Bedwell's company.''The Two Lost Girls: The Mystery of the Grimes Sisters'' {{ISBN|978-1-892-52398-3}} p. 57}} The autopsy reports upon both girls also supported Bedwell's recantation, as no alcohol or hot dogs were found in either victim's blood or digestive systems,{{cite news|last=Gavzer|first=Bernard|title=Pathology Report Says Grimes Girls Died Of Exposure|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=WZxJAAAAIBAJ&pg=1837,1390404|accessdate=April 2, 2013|newspaper=The News and Courier|date=February 9, 1957}} nor had the girls been beaten to death. Furthermore, Bedwell is also known to have clocked in at Ajax Consolidated Company, his place of employment, from 4:19 p.m. on December 28, 1956, to 12:30 am on December 29, covering the time period of the sisters' most likely abduction, with further records confirming Bedwell had been working in [[Cicero, Illinois|Cicero]] on the date he claimed to have murdered them. On February 6, Bedwell was freed on a $20,000 bond paid for by an individual from [[Champaign, Illinois|Champaign]].{{refn|group=n|All charges filed against Bedwell would be officially dropped on March 4''The Two Lost Girls: The Mystery of the Grimes Sisters'' {{ISBN|978-1-892-52398-3}} p. 93 due to the numerous inconsistencies in his confession in relation to the [[real evidence|physical]] and [[circumstantial evidence]] obtained and determined. Furthermore, Bedwell was officially classified as being a mentally retarded individual.''Crimes of the Centuries: Notorious Crimes, Criminals, and Criminal Trials in American History'' {{ISBN|978-1-610-69594-7}} p. 326}} The same year of his acquittal, Bedwell would be tried and acquitted of the 1956 rape of a 13-year-old girl in [[Oak Hill, Florida|Oak Hill]], Florida.{{cite news|title=Reports of Progress |date=January 1, 1958 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1873&dat=19580101&id=FZMeAAAAIBAJ&pg=676,48420 |publisher=Daytona Beach Morning Journal |accessdate=April 1, 2018}} He died in November 1972.''The Two Lost Girls: The Mystery of the Grimes Sisters'' {{ISBN|978-1-892-52398-3}} p. 146 ===Max Fleig=== Max Fleig was a 17-year-old suspect in the sisters' murders. Initially considered one of the prime suspects, due to his age, Fleig was protected by contemporary [[Law of Illinois|Illinois law]]s which prevented juveniles from subjection to [[polygraph|polygraph test]]s. Nonetheless, Chicago Police Captain Ralph Petacque persuaded the teenager to submit to an unofficial polygraph test, which Fleig voluntarily undertook.''True Crime: Illinois: The State's Most Notorious Criminal Cases'' {{ISBN|978-0-811-73562-9}} pp. 106-107 In the course of this unofficial polygraph test, Fleig allegedly confessed to the murders.''Chicago Haunts: Ghostlore of the Windy City'' {{ISBN|0-96424-269-9}} p. 141 With no legal means of using this test as evidence against Fleig,''True Crime: Illinois: The State's Most Notorious Criminal Cases'' {{ISBN|978-0-811-73562-9}} p. 106 police were forced to release him without charge. In addition, police were unable to charge Fleig with the murders due to there being a lack of [[real evidence|physical evidence]] corroborating his unofficial polygraph confession that he had kidnapped and subsequently killed the sisters.{{refn|group=n|When Lorretta Grimes was informed that [[Law of Illinois|Illinois law]] prohibited juveniles from subjection to [[polygraph|polygraph test]]ing, she praised police efforts to persuade Fleig to submit to an unofficial polygraph test, but publicly slated the Law of Illinois which protected an alleged murderer simply due to his age.''Chicago Haunts: Ghostlore of the Windy City'' {{ISBN|0-96424-269-9}} pp. 141-142}} Fleig was later jailed for the unrelated murder of a young woman. ===Walter Kranz=== Walter Kranz, a 53-year-old [[pipefitter|steamfitter]] and self-proclaimed [[psychic]], phoned a switchboard operator at Chicago's central police complaint room on January 15 to inform the operator of his conviction that both sisters were deceased and that their bodies could be found in an unincorporated area of [[Lyons Township, Cook County, Illinois|Lyons Township]]. Kranz refused to disclose his name to the operator in this phone call, simply stating that he had experienced this [[revelation]] in a dream, before terminating the call. Nonetheless, the operator was able to trace the call to a location close to his home. The park described by Kranz in his telephone call would prove to be approximately one mile from the true location where the girls' bodies would be just found one week later.{{cite news|title=Wide Hunt Opened For Girls' Slayers|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=J7YyAAAAIBAJ&pg=1863,3081816|accessdate=March 21, 2013|newspaper=The Miami News|date=January 23, 1957|author=Associated Press}} When questioned, Kranz informed police that several members of his family and ancestors possessed psychic powers, and that he had experienced this particular vision after a night of heavy drinking. Although initially considered by police to be their "number one suspect" in the murders, and with handwriting experts also determining he may have written a [[ransom note]] received by the girls' mother prior to the discovery of her daughters' bodies, Kranz denied any involvement in the sisters' abduction and murder. After being subjected to multiple interrogations, he was released. {{quote box | quote = "They were nice, ordinary little girls. Poor and happy—we all were. Their mother had to work and she assigned them housework, like mopping the floors. Our idea of fun was to pour soapy water over them and slide around in our bare feet, giggling—silly, little-kid stuff, you know? ... They might have accepted a ride with someone they knew to get warm. Either that, or someone forced them into a car." | source = Rosemary Chodor. Friend of Theresa Grimes, recollecting the three sisters' personalities.{{cite news|title=Death and the Maidens |date=March 20, 1997 |url=https://www.chicagoreader.com/chicago/death-and-the-maidens/Content?oid=892961 |publisher=Chicago Reader |accessdate=March 23, 2018}} | width = 30em }} ==Aftermath== In the weeks between the disappearance and subsequent discovery of her daughters' bodies, Lorretta Grimes was unable to work and thus earn money to raise her children and pay the mortgage upon her home. Friends and neighbors of the Grimes family—plus classmates and teachers of the sisters—organized various initiatives to raise funds for the family. Additional funds would be raised via the local press and council, with the donations raised via all various methods ranging from 50 cents to $500. Consequently, all funds raised would enable the Grimes family to both pay the remaining mortgage on their home and bury Barbara and Patricia's bodies.''The Two Lost Girls: The Mystery of the Grimes Sisters'' {{ISBN|978-1-892-52398-3}} pp. 42-43 Following a [[Wake (ceremony)|wake]] held in the girls' memory on January 25,''The Two Lost Girls: The Mystery of the Grimes Sisters'' {{ISBN|978-1-892-52398-3}} p. 44 and a [[Mass (liturgy)|Holy Mass]] conducted at St. Maurice Church, Barbara and Patricia Grimes were laid to rest at the Holy Sepulchre Cemetery in [[Worth, Illinois]], on January 28. All fees for the service were waived by the Wollschlager Funeral Home, and the sisters are buried side by side.{{cite web|title=Unsolved Chicago Grimes Sisters' Murder is 59 Years Old|url=http://www.chicagonow.com/chicago-history-cop/2015/12/unsolved-chicago-grimes-sisters-murder-is-59-years-old/ |website=chicagonow.com|accessdate=March 2, 2018|date=December 26, 2015}} Among those to serve [[pallbearer]]s at this service were classmates of Barbara's.''The Two Lost Girls: The Mystery of the Grimes Sisters'' {{ISBN|978-1-892-52398-3}} p. 45 In May 1957, Lorretta Grimes received an anonymous telephone call from an individual who claimed to have undressed and killed her daughters. Although the Grimes family had received numerous hoax phone calls following the girls' disappearance, this particular caller, having ridiculed police efforts to affix blame upon suspects such as Edward Bedwell, ended his phone call with information indicating he may indeed have been the perpetrator: "I know something about your little girl that no one else knows, not even the police. The smallest girl's toes were crossed at the feet!" This caller then laughed before terminating the call.''The Two Lost Girls: The Mystery of the Grimes Sisters'' {{ISBN|978-1-892-52398-3}} p. 109 One year after the murder of her daughters, Lorretta Grimes publicly stated her conviction her daughters had been murdered by an individual they had known, stating that although the weather had been bitterly cold on the night of their abduction, Barbara and Patricia would never have entered a vehicle driven by an individual unknown to them, regardless of any discomfort.''Chicago Haunts: Ghostlore of the Windy City'' {{ISBN|0-96424-269-9}} p. 142 Joseph Lohman, the Cook County Sheriff who strongly believed the Grimes sisters had been beaten, tortured and murdered by a sexual predator who had lured them into a vehicle on the evening of their disappearance, died of natural causes in 1969. At the time of his death, Lohman was the [[Dean (education)|Dean]] of the School of Criminology in [[Berkeley, California|Berkeley]].''The Two Lost Girls: The Mystery of the Grimes Sisters'' {{ISBN|978-1-892-52398-3}} p. 143 On the 18th anniversary of the disappearance of the Grimes sisters, Ernest Spiotto, the sole detective who had been involved in the investigation of the girls' murders from the very beginning and who remained assigned to the investigation, again announced to the media the police had no credible [[suspect]]s in the case.''Crimes of the Centuries: Notorious Crimes, Criminals, and Criminal Trials in American History'' {{ISBN|978-1-610-69594-7}} p. 326 Officially, the murders of the Grimes sisters remain unsolved, although this is an open case. The Grimes sisters' younger brother, James Grimes, who was just 11 at the time of his sisters' murder, stated in 2013 that he welcomed what he saw as a public "reopening of the case," stating: "I just assumed it was never going to be solved. [But] maybe there's hope."[http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2013-05-30/news/ct-talk-grimes-cold-case-20130530_1_2-sisters-west-chicago-police-officer "Murders of 2 sisters in 1956 getting new look"] by Naomi Nix, ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'', May 30, 2013 === Unofficial investigation === In 2013, a retired [[West Chicago]] police officer named Raymond Johnson began a personal investigation into the case. Johnson—considered by many to be an expert on this case—had become interested in the Grimes sisters' case in 2010,{{cite news|title=Grimes Sisters' Murder: Ray Johnson Wants to Solve Unsolved Deaths of Barbara and Patricia Grimes |date=May 31, 2013 |url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/05/31/grimes-sisters-murder-ray-johnson-solve_n_3366069.html |accessdate=March 3, 2018}} when he had been researching a book he had been writing about the city's history.[http://www.chicagonow.com/chicago-strange-haunted-history/2013/01/can-a-facebook-group-help-solve-grimes-sisters-murder#image/1 "Can a Facebook group Help Solve Grimes Sisters Murder?"] by Ray Johnson, [[ChicagoNow]], January 22, 2013 Having extensively researched the case, Johnson has stated his conviction that the case is still a solvable one, but only with public assistance,{{cite news|title=Unsolved Chicago Grimes Sisters’ Murder is 59 Years Old |date=December 26, 2015 |url=http://www.chicagonow.com/chicago-history-cop/2015/12/unsolved-chicago-grimes-sisters-murder-is-59-years-old/ |publisher=Chicagonow.com |accessdate=March 8, 2018}} and that he believes that the perpetrator of this crime had been a 23-year-old self-confessed child killer named Charles LeRoy Melquist, who had been considered a suspect in the sisters' abduction and murder in 1957.{{cite news|title=2 Investigators: The Unsolved 1956 Murder Of The Grimes Sisters |date=December 24, 2016 |url=http://chicago.cbslocal.com/2018/01/22/grimes-sisters-murder/ |publisher=CBS Chicago |accessdate=March 8, 2018}} Melquist had been convicted of the September 1958 murder of a 15-year-old girl named Bonnie Leigh Scott, whom he had known prior to her murder,''The Two Lost Girls: The Mystery of the Grimes Sisters'' {{ISBN|978-1-892-52398-3}} p. 107 and whose [[decapitation|decapitated]] body had been found two months after her disappearance less than 10 miles from where the Grimes sisters' bodies had been discovered.''The Two Lost Girls: The Mystery of the Grimes Sisters'' {{ISBN|978-1-892-52398-3}} p. 108 Following the discovery of Scott's body, investigators had noted similarities in this murder and body disposal, and that of the Grimes sisters. Nonetheless, Melquist was never questioned as to his potential [[culpability]] in the Grimes sisters' murders, as his attorney had forbade him to be subject to questioning.{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagonow.com/chicago-history-cop/2017/09/59th-anniversary-of-the-murder-of-bonnie-leigh-scott-of-addison-could-lead-to-closure-in-the-1956-grimes-sisters-murder/|title=59th Anniversary of the Murder of Bonnie Leigh Scott of Addison Could Lead to Closure in the 1956 Grimes Sisters' Murder |first=Raymond|last=Johnson|date=September 21, 1997|publisher=|via=chicagonow.com}} The day after the body of Bonnie Leigh Scott was discovered, Lorretta Grimes received a phone call from an individual who, on this occasion, claimed responsibility for Scott's murder. On this occasion, the caller had stated: "I've committed another perfect crime ... This is another one those cops won't solve and they're not going [to affix blame onto] Bedwell or Barry Cook."{{refn|group=n|Cook was a criminal incarcerated at the [[Joliet Correctional Center]] who had admitted then denied his involvement in two murders dating from 1957.}} Lorretta Grimes would remain adamant until her death this caller had been the same individual who had contacted her in May 1957 and had revealed the [[deformity]] upon one of her daughters' feet which had never been released to the press or the public, stating: "I will never forget that voice." Charles Melquist was never charged with his alleged involvement in the deaths of the Grimes sisters. He died in 2010.{{cite news|title=2 Investigators: The Unsolved 1956 Murder Of The Grimes Sisters |date=December 24, 2016 |url=http://chicago.cbslocal.com/2018/01/22/grimes-sisters-murder/ |publisher=CBS Chicago |accessdate=March 8, 2018}} ==See also== {{col-begin}} {{col-break}} * [[Cold case]] * [[Crime in Illinois]] * [[List of murdered American children]] {{col-break}} * [[List of people who disappeared mysteriously]] * [[Unsolved murders]] {{col-end}} {{Portalbar|1950s|Biography|Crime|Criminal justice|Illinois}} ==Notes== {{reflist|group=n}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==Cited works and further reading== *{{Cite book|last=Bailey|first=Frankie Y. {{Synthesis|date=May 2011}} {{refimprove|date=November 2016}} In [[Great Britain]], the term '''North–South divide''' refers to the economic and cultural differences between [[Southern England]] and the rest of Great Britain ([[Northern England]], [[The Midlands]], [[Wales]] and [[Scotland]]). The divide cuts through the [[English Midlands]]. Sometimes, the term is widened to include the whole [[United Kingdom]], with [[Northern Ireland]] included as part of "the North".
In political terms, the South, and particularly the [[South East England]] (outside [[inner London]]) and [[East of England]], is largely centre-right, and supportive of the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]], while the Greater North (particularly the towns and cities) is generally more supportive of the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] as well as, in Scotland, the [[Scottish National Party|SNP]]. Support for the [[Liberal Democrats (UK)|Liberal Democrats]], and for many of the smaller parties, is generally more equally spread out. There is some criticism of this analysis in the [[West Country]] which, until the [[United Kingdom general election, 2015|May 2015 UK general election]], had consistently provided a solid base for the Liberal Democrats, and also in places (particularly parts of [[Bristol]], [[Devon]], and [[Cornwall]]) which suffer from many of the same economic problems as the North.
==Existence== The North-South divide is not an exact line, but one that can involve many stereotypes, presumptions and other impressions of the surrounding region relative to other regions.
The existence of the North-South divide is fiercely contested. Some sources claim it exists but also that it is even expanding. For example, a report in 2001 found that North East England, [[North West England]] and Scotland had poorer health levels than South.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Doran, Tim |author2=Drever, Frances |author3=Whitehead, Margaret | date = 1 May 2004 | url=http://bmj.bmjjournals.com/cgi/content/abstract/328/7447/1043?ijkey=76a2ead76e6828d38e96cd46ded8f235930215ca&keytype2=tf_ipsecsha |format = | title=Is there a north-south divide in social class inequalities in health in Great Britain? Cross sectional study using data from the 2001 census | publisher = | accessdate = 2006-07-16 }}</ref>
The same data have been interpreted otherwise to indicate only a very small difference.<ref>{{cite news | first = J Martin | last = Bland | authorlink = Martin Bland | url = http://bmj.bmjjournals.com/cgi/content/full/329/7456/52 | title = North-south divide in social inequalities in Great Britain | publisher = British Medical Journal | date = 3 July 2004 | accessdate = 2006-07-16 }}</ref>
Indeed, results are highly dependent on the categories chosen for evaluation. As a generalisation, the following tend to indicate that there is some sort of north-south divide:
*Health conditions, which are generally seen as being worse in the north,<ref>{{cite news | first = John | last = Carvel | url = https://www.theguardian.com/northsouth/article/0,,1640082,00.html | title = Wide life expectancy gap between rich and poor | publisher = The Guardian | date = 11 November 2005 | accessdate = 2006-07-16 | location=London}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | first = James | last = Meikle | url = https://www.theguardian.com/britain/article/0,,1522036,00.html | title = Cancer atlas reveals north-south divide | publisher = The Guardian | date = 6 July 2005 | accessdate = 2006-07-16 | location=London}}</ref> though spending on health care is higher <ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.reform.co.uk/Research/ResearchArticles/tabid/82/smid/378/ArticleID/1217/reftab/161/Default.aspx|title=Public sector finances: views from the inside|last=|first=|date=|work=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110622033100/http://www.reform.co.uk/Research/ResearchArticles/tabid/82/smid/378/ArticleID/1217/reftab/161/Default.aspx|archive-date=22 June 2011|access-date=|via=}}</ref> *House prices, which are higher in the south, particularly the South-East.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/shared/spl/hi/in_depth/uk_house_prices/html/houses.stm | title = UK House Prices | accessdate = 2006-07-16 | date = 8 May 2006 | publisher = BBC News }}</ref> *Earnings, which are higher in the south and east.<ref>{{cite news | first = John | last = Carvel | url = https://www.theguardian.com/northsouth/article/0,,1638884,00.html | title = North-south, east-west wealth divides in survey | publisher = The Guardian | date = 10 November 2005 | accessdate = 2006-07-16 | location=London}}</ref> *Government spending per person on drivers of growth such as transport, infrastructure and R&D, which is far higher in the South-East.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.ippr.org/press-releases/111/8456/transport-spend-per-head-is-p2700-for-london-but-p5-per-head-in-north-east | title = Transport spend per head is £2,700 for London but £5 per head in North East | publisher = IPPR North | date = 19 December 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.ippr.org/publication/55/9949/northern-prosperity-is-national-prosperity-a-strategy-for-revitalising-the-uk-economy | title = Northern prosperity is national prosperity: A strategy for revitalising the UK economy | publisher = IPPR North, NEFC | date = 29 November 2012 }}</ref> *Government expenditure per person, which is higher (both in gross terms and relative to tax revenues), in the North than the South; largely to fund universal benefits as a result of higher unemployment.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-487058/The-REAL-north-south-divide-How-South-East-bankrolling-Britain.html | title = The REAL north-south divide How South East bankrolling Britain | publisher = The Daily Mail | date = 12 October 2007 | location=London | first=Steve | last=Doughty}}</ref> *Political influence.<ref>{{cite news | first = Larry | last = Elliott | url = https://www.theguardian.com/northsouth/article/0,,1638884,00.html | title = The United Kingdom of London | publisher = The Guardian | date = 5 July 2004 | accessdate = 2006-07-16 }}</ref> *Devolution of powers to local government. London has a directly elected mayor with control over public transport whilst most Northern cities do not have mayors and have transport policies decided by the UK government.
However, many [[middle-class]] and affluent areas are located near most major cities north of the divide, and conversely there are pockets of large deprivation in the south. A report into wealth by [[Barclays Bank]] also highlighted the anomaly that the wealthiest parliamentary constituency outside London is actually [[Sheffield Hallam (UK Parliament constituency)|Sheffield Hallam]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/3871857.stm | work=BBC News | title=Wealth hotspots 'outside London' | date=7 July 2004}}</ref> A 2012 survey by [[Halifax Building Society|Halifax]] stated that whilst nine of the top ten most expensive places to live in Britain were in the south of England, [[Edinburgh]] was ninth on the list, ahead of [[Salisbury]].<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/property/uk/the-10-most-expensive-and-least-expensive-cities-in-britain/bagpipers-stroll-down-the-road-in-edinburgh/ | work=Daily Telegraph | title=The 10 most expensive and least expensive cities in Britain | date=14 October 2012 | accessdate=8 December 2016}}</ref>
This has led some commentators to suggest that other divisions, such as class<ref>{{cite news | first = Kamal | last = Ahmed | url = http://observer.guardian.co.uk/education/story/0,12554,837171,00.html | title = Britain's class divide starts even before nursery school | publisher = The Observer | date = 10 November 2002 | accessdate = 2006-07-16 | location=London}}</ref> or ethnicity might be more important.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.dwp.gov.uk/publications/dwp/2006/poverty/tackling-poverty.pdf | title = Making a difference: Tackling poverty - a progress report | accessdate = 2006-07-16 | date = March 2006 | format = PDF | publisher = Department for Work and Pensions | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060725160232/http://www.dwp.gov.uk/publications/dwp/2006/poverty/tackling-poverty.pdf | archivedate = 25 July 2006 | df = dmy-all }}</ref>
There is also controversy as to what constitutes the South given that it extends much farther longitudinally than the North of the country; some commentators have placed the [[West Country]] (in this case, Bristol,<ref name="Bristol: State of the City" group="">{{cite news|last=Clark|first=Dave|title=Mr|url=http://www.bristol.gov.uk/ccm/cms-service/stream/asset/?asset_id=36498092|accessdate=15 July 2011|date=15 July 2011}}</ref> Somerset, Devon and Cornwall) into a region of its own because the poverty in some of these areas is often as widespread as it is in the North, and political support is also focused on the usually widespread Liberal Democrats, until the 2015 general election when the Conservatives took virtually all the seats west of Bristol.
==Politics== {{unreferenced section|date=January 2012}} The North has been generally perceived as being supportive of [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]] as well as in Scotland the [[Scottish National Party|SNP]] and the South being generally supportive of the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservatives]]. During the 1980s, Labour councils in the North were often openly dismissive of any orders from the [[Margaret Thatcher|Thatcher]] government. Examples include [[Liverpool]] under the [[Militant tendency]] and [[Sheffield]] under [[David Blunkett]]. Furthermore, after the [[United Kingdom general election, 2010|2010 General election]], the Conservatives held only one seat in Scotland and none in the major cities of [[Manchester]], [[Liverpool]], [[Newcastle upon Tyne|Newcastle]], [[Glasgow]], [[Edinburgh]], [[Kingston upon Hull|Hull]] and [[Sheffield]] all of which were dominated by [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]]. The Conservatives hold two seats in [[Leeds]]. It can also be noted that major city councils in southern England tend to swing politically between Labour and Conservative control, despite being located in a wider region dominated singularly by the Conservatives. Examples of this include the cities of [[Southampton]] and [[Plymouth]].
==See also== *[[North–South divide]] *[[North–South divide (England)]] *[[Geography and identity in Wales|North–South divide (Wales)]] *[[Scottish Highlands]] and [[Scottish Lowlands]] *[[North Britain]] and [[South Britain]] *[[Lloegyr]]

{{for|the Japanese lexical law|Ōno's lexical law}}
'''Ohno's law''' was proposed by a Japanese-American biologist [[Susumu Ohno]], saying that the [[gene]] content of the [[mammal]]ian [[species]] has been conserved over species not only in the [[DNA]] content but also in the genes themselves. That is, nearly all mammalian species have conserved the [[X chromosome]] from their primordial X chromosome of a common ancestor.<ref name=Ohno67>Ohno S (1967). ''Sex Chromosomes and sex-linked genes.'' Berlin:Springer-Verlag.</ref>
== Evidence == As a [[Cell biology|cytological]] evidence, in first, mammalian X chromosomes in various species, including [[human]] and [[mouse]], have nearly the same size, with the content of about 5% of the genome. Second, for individual [[Locus (genetics)|gene loci]], a number of X-linked genes are common through mammalian species. Examples are found in [[glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase]] (G6PD), a gene for polypeptide of [[antihemophilic globulin]] (AHG or [[Factor VIII]]) in [[Haemophilia A|hemophilia A]] and [[Haemophilia B|B]], and plasma thromboplastin component gene (PTC or [[Factor IX]]). Moreover, no instances were found where an [[Sex linkage|X-linked]] gene in one species was located on an [[autosome]] in the other species.<ref name=Ohno67 />
== Conservation mechanisms == The content of a chromosome would be changed mainly by mutation after duplication of the chromosome and translocation with other chromosomes. However, in mammals, since the chromosomal [[Sex-determination system|sex-determination]] mechanism would have been established in their earlier stages of [[evolution]], [[polyploidy]] would have not occurred due to its incompatibility with the sex-determining mechanism. Moreover, X-autosome [[Chromosomal translocation|translocation]] would have been prohibited because it might have resulted in detrimental effects for survival to the organism. Thus in mammals, the content of X chromosomes has been conserved after typical 2 round duplication events at early ancestral stages of evolution, at the fish or amphibia ([[2R hypothesis]]).<ref name=Ohno67 /><ref name=Ohno70>Ohno S (1970). ''Evolution by Gene Duplication.'' London: Allen and Unwin, {{ISBN|0-04-575015-7}}.</ref>
== Contradicting and supportive evidence == Genes on the long arm of the human X are contained in the monotreme X and genes on the short arm of the human X are distributed on the autosomes of marsupials.<ref name=Watson>Watson JM, Riggs A, Graves JA (1992). "Gene mapping studies confirm the homology between the platypus X and echidna X1 chromosomes and identify a conserved ancestral monotreme X chromosome". ''Chromosoma'' 101(10): 596–601, {{PMID|1424984}}.</ref> Ohno commented to the result that [[monotreme]]s and [[marsupial]]s were not considered to be ancestors of true mammals, but they have diverged very early from the main line of mammals.<ref name=Ohno93>Ohno S (1993). "Patterns in genome evolution". ''Curr Opin Genet Dev'' 3(6): 911–914, {{PMID|8118217}}.</ref> [[Chloride channel]] gene (''CLCN4'') was mapped to the human X but on chromosome 7 of C57BL/6 mice, species of [[House Mouse|''Mus musculus'']], though the gene is located on X of [[Algerian Mouse|''Mus spretus'']] and [[rat]].<ref name=Palmer>Palmer S, Perry J, Ashworth A (1995). "A contravention of ohno's law in mice". ''Nat Genet'' 10(4): 472–476, {{PMID|7670497}}, {{DOI|10.1038/ng0895-472}}.</ref>
== Dictionaries having an article's name of ‘Ohno ‘s law’ == * Rédei GP (2003). "Ohno's law." ''Encyclopedic dictionary of genetics, genomics, and proteomics, 2nd ed.'' New York: Wiley-Liss, p. 870. {{ISBN|0-471-26821-6}}.
